scene.name: bread
scene.line: Exactly. That's the work of our unique ingredient — the yeast. The story is that Mr. Bishop got it from a baker in Knoxville, in a little tin box.
He was on the run, our Mr. Bishop, from the law. For a while he hid out in some muddy swamp, subsisting on live fish, but he always kept that little tin box dry, held above his head.
Some among us have proposed that a bit of swamp water seeped in that little tin box, introducing a foreign element, and giving our yeast culture the eccentricity for which it's so widely known.

I think it was that baker in Knoxville. They arrested him years later, for the possession of a controlled substance. Life in prison. Solitary confinement. No visitors, no windows, 'til the day he died.
Must have been a hell of a substance, hey?

scene.name: oil
scene.line: That sickly-sweet, hypnotic aroma, like twilight at an all-night filling station. It's the mash. We use a distinctive `accelerant` when cooking it.
Don't ask me what it's called — it hasn't got a name. A dark, viscous fluid. It arrives monthly, in unlabeled barrels on a horse-drawn cart.
A descendant of one of Mr. Bishop's `friends` delivers it. Silent, middle-aged woman. That family is still somehow in debt to us, I'm sure of that.
